When we look at the actual death rates per unit of energy produced—measured in deaths per terawatt-hour (TWh)—the evidence clearly shows that coal is more dangerous than nuclear power.

The most comprehensive and widely cited study on this topic was conducted by the University of Manchester and published in 2013. It analyzed the death rates from various energy sources over their entire lifecycle, including mining, processing, operation, and waste. According to this study, coal causes approximately 160 deaths per TWh, while nuclear power causes about 0.07 deaths per TWh. That's more than 2,000 times more deaths from coal than from nuclear energy.

The reason for this stark difference lies in the nature of the two energy sources. Coal mining and burning are associated with a wide range of health hazards. Miners face deadly accidents, lung diseases like black lung, and long-term respiratory issues. When burned, coal releases harmful pollutants such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter, and mercury, all of which contribute to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, cancer, and premature deaths—often in densely populated areas near power plants.

In contrast, nuclear power plants are designed with multiple layers of safety, and their operation involves very few direct fatalities. When we do see deaths related to nuclear power, they're often associated with major accidents like Chernobyl or Fukushima. However, even when accounting for these rare but high-profile events, the death rate per TWh remains significantly lower than that of coal.

So, while nuclear accidents can be catastrophic when they occur, they are extremely rare and their impact is limited in terms of overall deaths when compared to the consistent and widespread toll of coal. In fact, the World Health Organization estimates that air pollution from coal-fired power plants causes hundreds of thousands of premature deaths each year—far more than any nuclear incident in history.
